unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Independent or Not?
question_text: If two events, $A$ and $B$, are independent, then which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Knowing whether or not event $A$ occurs does not alter the probability that event $B$ will occur.
$p\left( A \text{ and } B \right) =p(A)\cdot p(B)-p(A \text{ or } B)$

solution:
Choice 'B' is a false statement and confuses the addition rule with the multiplication rule.

The addition rule states:

$$p(A \text{ or } B) = p(A) + p(B) - p(A \text{ and } B)$$

We cannot simply interchange the words “and” and “or” while also interchanging arithmetic operations. It is not true that:

$$p(A \text{ and } B) = p(A)\cdot p(B)-p(A \text{ or } B) $$

Choices 'A' and 'D' are equivalent answers expressed in different ways. Choice 'A' uses words while Choice 'D' uses notation.

Both are true statements for independent events $A$ and $B$. Choice 'C' is also a true statement and simply reverses events $A$ and $B$.

Choice 'E' is a true statement for independent events $A$ and $B$.
